message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history and symptoms suggest cervical spine injury, and the best test to confirm this is MRI of the cervical spine without contrast. CT angiography of the neck is used to diagnose arterial injuries. Cervical myelography is an older technique that has largely been replaced by MRI. X-ray of the cervical spine can show fractures or other bony abnormalities but not soft tissue injuries.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient shows signs of cervical spine injury with neurologic impairment, so imaging is necessary. CT angiography and cervical myelography may be used, but MRI of the cervical spine without contrast is most likely to confirm the cause of the patient's neurologic examination findings. X-ray of the cervical spine may be used as a screening tool, but MRI is more sensitive and specific for detecting soft tissue injuries.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the patient's history indicate a possible cervical spinal cord injury, and MRI without contrast is the most sensitive imaging modality for detecting spinal cord injuries, according to current guidelines. CT angiography, cervical myelography, and x-ray of the cervical spine may not provide sufficient detail to confirm the cause of the patient's neurologic examination findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms suggestive of spinal cord injury, and MRI of the cervical spine without contrast is the best choice to confirm the cause of the findings. CT angiography of the neck would not provide information on the spinal cord injury. Cervical myelography and X-ray of the cervical spine are not as sensitive or specific as MRI for detecting spinal cord injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has suffered a trauma and has symptoms of neck pain and weakness of the upper extremities. MRI of the cervical spine without contrast is the most appropriate imaging technique to confirm the cause of the patient's neurological examination findings. It can provide detailed images of the spinal cord and surrounding structures and can help identify any spinal cord injuries or compression. CT angiography of the neck, cervical myelography, and x-ray of the cervical spine may not provide enough detail to confirm the cause of the patient's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has midline cervical tenderness and neurologic examination findings suggestive of spinal cord injury. MRI without contrast is the most sensitive and specific method to identify spinal cord injury, including cord edema, hemorrhage or contusion, and spinal cord compression. CT angiography of the neck is used to visualize vascular structures, cervical myelography is an old method to visualize spinal cord, and x-ray of the cervical spine can identify fractures but not soft tissue injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's fall and symptoms suggest a cervical spine injury, and MRI of the cervical spine without contrast is the most accurate imaging study to confirm this. CT angiography would be used to evaluate vasculature, cervical myelography is a more invasive test, and X-ray may not show soft tissue injuries as accurately as MRI.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. This patient’s symptoms suggest spinal cord injury, and MRI of the cervical spine without contrast is the best imaging study to confirm the diagnosis. CT angiography of the neck is not indicated for a suspected spinal cord injury. Cervical myelography and X-ray of the cervical spine are inferior to MRI in diagnosing spinal cord injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's history and physical examination findings suggest a cervical spine injury. MRI of the cervical spine without contrast is the most accurate study for evaluating the spinal cord and soft tissue injuries. CT angiography is used to evaluate vascular injuries, such as dissection or aneurysm, which is not indicated in this case. Cervical myelography and X-ray of the cervical spine are less accurate than MRI.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient seems to be experiencing spinal cord injury from the fall. MRI of the cervical spine without contrast is the best way to confirm and assess the extent of the injury. CT angiography of the neck is not necessary in this case. X-ray of the cervical spine and cervical myelography may identify fractures or narrowing of the spinal canal, but they are less sensitive than MRI for identifying soft tissue injuries.
